turn.0: Hi, I'm your automated assistant. I can answer your questions about Sauble River (Ontario).
turn.2: Sauble River (Ontario) The Sauble River is a river in Bruce County and Grey County in southwestern Ontario, Canada that flows from its headwaters in the township of Chatsworth to Lake Huron at the community of Sauble Beach.
turn.3: Is there anything interesting about the river?
turn.4: The river was originally called "Rivière aux Saubles", or "sandy river", by the French.
turn.6: It was named the River aux Saubles on maps until 1881, when it became the Sauble River.
turn.7: Was there ever any settlements along the river?
turn.8: When first settled, the area included a sawmill and later, a hydro electric plant.
turn.10: The Sauble River begins at an unnamed pond in the township of Chatsworth in Grey County, between the communities of Desboro to the north and Mooresburg to the south.
turn.12: It heads north then west, takes in the left tributary Grimston Creek and right tributary Keady Creek, passes along the border to the municipality of Arran–Elderslie in Bruce County near the community of Grimston, before entering that municipality and reaching the community of Tara, where it takes in the left tributary Tara Creek.
